name: Yoruba Mythology
description: Discover Yoruba traditions of Olodumare, the Orisha intermediaries, and the power of Ashe.
overview: Yoruba mythology from West Africa centers on Olodumare (supreme creator) who governs through Orisha - divine spirits embodying natural forces, human archetypes, and ancestral wisdom. Key Orisha include Eshu (trickster/messenger), Ogun (iron/war), Shango (thunder/kingship), Oshun (river/love), Yemoja (ocean/motherhood), and Obatala (creation/wisdom). The tradition emphasizes Ashe (divine power/life force), divination through Ifa, ancestor veneration, and maintaining balance between visible and spiritual worlds. Yoruba religion influenced diaspora traditions including Santeria, Candomble, and Vodou.

sections.title: The Orisha
sections.body:
**Olodumare:** Supreme creator, too vast to worship directly

**Obatala:** Creator of human bodies, wisdom, purity
**Ogun:** Iron, technology, war, clearing paths
**Shango:** Thunder, drums, masculine power, justice
**Oshun:** River, love, beauty, fertility, diplomacy
**Yemoja:** Ocean, motherhood, nurturing, protection
**Oya:** Wind, storms, transformation, female warriors
**Eshu:** Trickster, messenger, crossroads, divine enforcer

Each Orisha has specific colors, offerings, taboos, and areas of influence.
